title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Republican John Deaton announces run for Sen. Ed Markey's seat after losing to Elizabeth Warren.
Deaton, 58, emphasizes his independence and highlights his background as a Marine veteran and lawyer.
Ed Markey, 80, faces primary challenge from Seth Moulton for the 2026 Senate election.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox aim to acquire a top pitcher to complement ace Garrett Crochet for playoff readiness, says chief baseball officer Craig Breslow.
Team might pursue trades for pitchers like Joe Ryan or explore free agents such as Dylan Cease and Ranger Suarez.
Red Sox seek to add power hitters to their lineup, considering sluggers like Kyle Schwarber or Pete Alonso.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara, a former Boston Bruins captain, was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame on Monday.
Chara signed a $37.5 million contract with the Bruins in 2006, initiating a long-term period of success.
In 2012, Chara set the NHL record for the hardest shot with a 108.8 mph slap shot.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick navigates a 'learning curve' in his first season coaching UNC, which is 4-5 in the ACC.
UNC needs to win two of their last three games to match last year's six-win total under fired coach Mack Brown.
Belichick emphasizes improving player positioning and utilizing experiences to inform coaching strategies at UNC.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 15 players from the New England Patriots are listed on Monday's injury report ahead of Thursday's game against the Jets.
Kayshon Boutte (hamstring) and Rhamondre Stevenson (toe) were limited participants in practice after missing Sunday's game.
Tight end Austin Hooper did not participate in Monday's practice due to a concussion, affecting Patriots' preparation time.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, of Atlanta, faces 25 charges, including larceny and money laundering, over unclaimed Massachusetts property fraud.
Stayman allegedly submitted false claims to Massachusetts' unclaimed property division, receiving $1.1 million and attempting to claim $2.2 million more.
His bail is set at $2 million; he's also awaiting sentencing in a separate federal case for charges in Alabama.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson scored a key touchdown after glancing at the sideline for coaching guidance late in the game.
The fourth-quarter touchdown capped Henderson's best career performance, surpassing 100 rushing yards and recording multiple touchdowns.
With Rhamondre Stevenson out, Henderson's role has increased, as Patriots manage running back depth amid injuries.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Boston Bruins lineup against the Toronto Maple Leafs, recording two assists in a 5-3 win.
Lohrei had been benched for five games due to defensive struggles, replaced by Jonathan Aspirot as the Bruins won five consecutive games.
Bruins players, including Lohrei, Casey Mittelstadt, Marat Khusnutdinov, and Johnny Beecher, have responded strongly to coach Marco Sturm's lineup challenges.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: The Coalition for a Healthy Massachusetts is gathering signatures for a ballot to repeal recreational marijuana laws.
State officials have received complaints about misleading tactics by signature gatherers for the marijuana repeal petition.
Cannabis business advocates claim the signature effort includes deceptive practices akin to 'organized voter fraud.'

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, a slight decrease from last year's $10.26 billion.
University of Massachusetts topped payroll rankings with the top 15 highest-paid state employees, totaling $1.55 billion in expenditures.
The MBTA ranked second with $799.68 million in payroll, followed by the state's Trial Court at $574.67 million.
